title: How AFLW gave football the kick it needed
text:
Source: FOX SPORTS A NINE-YEAR headstart, gone in a flash. 
That’s what confronted the W-League when the AFL Women’s competition launched amid a flock of hype and plaudits this year. 
For years, football has had the opportunity to capture the hearts and minds of both football fans and the country’s top female athletes through a national competition. 
Yet for too long, the sport has stalled — with salaries and working conditions for the majority of players not up to scratch — and it has been found out, with fans and athletes both flocking to the AFLW in numbers. 
But the PFA’s new road map for women’s football shapes as a key opportunity for football to regain some of the ground it has lost. 
With increased pay opportunities and professionalism in the W-League the main focus of the road map, chief executive John Didulica said the plan would play a key role in keeping footballers in the round ball game. 
“That’s the core challenge and one of the challenges that this vision seeks to address,” Didulica said on Tuesday. 
“Ultimately the quality of our footballers generally is high. They’ve got great vision, dexterity, mobility. 
“They’re wonderful athletes and if we allow these players to get to 17 or 18 or 19 and not have an effective career ahead of them, we do risk losing them to other sports.” 
EXPLAINED: GRAND PLAN TO RE-WRITE WOMEN’S FOOTBALL 
The PFA say plans to reinvigorate the W-League have been in the works for close to a year, yet there’s no doubt the rapid rise and success of the AFL competition has escalated the need to publicly press for lifting its professionalism and profile. 
While the AFLW does compete with the W-League for both viewers and athletes, its remarkable first-season success has been part of a massive lift in publicity and public support for women’s sport. 
PFA Player Relations Executive and former Matilda Kathryn Gill said the AFLW and WBBL had exposed the potential of women’s sport. 
“I guess the new competitions have highlighted the demand for women’s sport in general,” Gill said. 
“Now ... we’re running out of seats at stadiums to watch women playing AFL. 
“I think it’s fantastic, it’s changed the landscape and we’re now going to play our part in even further enhancing that.” Melbourne City celebrate their win. Source: AAP 
As always with women’s sport, improved pay and working conditions are a key part of developing the game. 
Under the PFA’s planned model, 60 W-League players would earn at least $60,000 per year through W-League, Matildas and either overseas or employment contracts. 
But the biggest impact would be felt in the middle and lower tiers of players. 
In 2016, 85 per cent of W-League players earned less than $5,000 for the season, with 25 per cent earning less than $500. 
To put it in contrast, the AFLW’s lowest ranked players will earn at least $8,000 for the inaugural season. 
It’s no wonder athletes would consider switching codes, like ex-Matilda Brianna Davey — or at least playing two sports, like Camberra United’s Ellie Brush and Jenna McCormick do for AFLW clubs Greater Western Sydney and Adelaide respectively. Brianna Davey. Source: News Corp Australia 
If the PFA get their way, ‘seasoned professionals’ would earn at least $11,500 for a season while the ‘amateur’ category, mostly comprised of young players elevated from NPL clubs, would be in line for an allowance likely to be around the $2,500 mark — though their contracts would be shaped differently to the professionals. 
The pay would be part of an increased professionalism where women’s football would have a 12-month program, including an extended, 18-games-plus-finals W-League season. 
With a focus on developing players over a four-year cycle, the aim would be to keep players focused on football, year-round — which would also work to keep them away from other codes. 
“I wouldn’t anticipate that any player who had an opportunity to play as a professional footballer over a four-year cycle would opt out of that for a short-term deal in another code,” Didulica said. 
Well beyond competing with other local football codes, the PFA road map focuses on creating a talent pool deep enough to compete with the best in the world. 
The plan is based upon challenging for a gold medal at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, then glory at the 2019 Women’s World Cup in France. 
In order to achieve that, football needs to produce a talent pool deep enough to match it with the world’s best. Caitlin Foord of Australia celebrates scoring a goal. Source: Getty Images 
“Our challenge is twofold,” Didulica said. 
“Firstly it’s to convince them (the players) to fall in love with the game and make it their calling. 
“The second part is then to set ourselves up to take on the real competitions, who are the USA, Sweden, Germany, France. 
“They’re the people we’re up against in football — it’s not the AFL or the Big Bash, it’s other nations who want to take away our Olympic gold medal or a World Cup trophy.” 
But as always, the key to developing that talent pool — rather than losing it to other sports — will be capturing the hearts and minds of young players. 
If the FFA takes the PFA recommendations on board, it will be one more step towards fostering that talent pool. 
But visibility and awareness — something AFLW and WBBL have driven with strong campaigns based on female athletes as role models — remain a key part of starting the journey. 
“More important is making sure they know there is a pathway and a professional league they can go into,” PFA executive member and Sydney FC footballer Gabe Marzano said. 
“Because over the past decade, probably 90 per cent of the female players at grassroots level don’t even know there’s a W-League. 
“That in itself just amplifies the fact that there needs to be more professionalism behind the W-League, more commercialism, better marketing. 
“These grassroots players need to know that you can play with the boys until you’re 13 and then of course you can go and play in a national professional competition and not be taken away by the AFLW.” View All Comments The latest sports news, in your inbox daily. Email
